author: By Isabelle Taft
title: Dashed Hopes and Big Breaks: What It’s Like to Work on Cold Cases
description: This month, significant breakthroughs were announced in several murder cases that had been dormant for decades. Investigators explained what cracking these can look like.
content: Thomas Elfmont, a retired Los Angeles police officer, was living in Bozeman, Mont., when the local sheriff invited him to lunch. Over Mexican food, the sheriff described the murder of a 15-year-old girl that rocked a nearby small town almost 30 years ago and had never been solved. The sheriff asked: Would Mr. Elfmont take it on?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Grand Canyon Hiker Missing After Flash Floods and Evacuations
description: More than 100 people were evacuated after flash flooding in the Havasupai Indian Reservation near Grand Canyon National Park.
content: A hiker remained missing on Sunday, according to the National Park Service, and more than 100 people were evacuated after flash flooding at a remote reservation on the border of Grand Canyon National Park.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Mazzetti, Ronen Bergman, Julian E. Barnes and Adam Goldman
title: Israel’s Hunt for the Elusive Leader of Hamas
description: Yahya Sinwar’s ability to evade capture or death has denied Israel a military success in a war that began after he planned the Oct. 7 attacks.
content: In January, Israeli and American officials thought they had caught a break in the hunt for one of the world’s most wanted men.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: An Impressive Monument to Christopher Isherwood, Man of Letters (and Lovers)
description: Though it downplays unflattering details, Katherine Bucknell’s big biography hails the 20th-century writer as an early advocate for the “chosen family.”
content: Many writers’ graves are tourist attractions. Not Christopher Isherwood’s. Indeed, he doesn’t have one. Best remembered for his “Berlin Stories,” which became “I Am a Camera” which became “Cabaret” — and latterly for “A Single Man,” which the designer Tom Ford made into a movie — Isherwood, who died in 1986 at 81, signed away his corpse to science.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: After Attacks, Israel and Hezbollah Swiftly Move to Talk of Containment
description: Hezbollah’s long-dreaded retaliation for the killing of a senior commander appeared to be over before it began. But analysts said tensions could yet escalate further.
content: For weeks, Israelis have waited in trepidation for a major attack by Hezbollah in retaliation for Israel’s assassination of a senior commander of the Lebanese group in Beirut last month, amid widespread fears that a cross-border escalation could spiral into an all-out regional war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut and Daria Mitiuk
title: Battle-Hardened Poets Fuel a Literary Revival in Ukraine
description: With verses that capture the raw emotions of the war and resonate deeply with the population, Ukrainian poets have emerged as some of the country’s most influential voices.
content: For several days in March 2022, the battalion of Yaryna Chornohuz, a Ukrainian poet and combat medic, faced fierce attacks from a column of Russian tanks in southeastern Ukraine. Outgunned, the soldiers repelled the first two assaults, but suffered many casualties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Russell Malone, Acclaimed Jazz Guitarist, Dies at 60
description: He first gained attention with Jimmy Smith and went on to work with Harry Connick Jr., Diana Krall and Ron Carter. He also had a distinguished solo career.
content: Russell Malone, a jazz guitarist whose encyclopedic knowledge of musicians and songs, combined with a precise yet relaxed playing style, earned him jobs with Harry Connick Jr., Diana Krall and many others, as well as a dedicated following as a solo artist, died on Friday in Tokyo. He was 60.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Fashion and the Convention
description: The Times’s fashion critic explores the deliberate choices behind politicians’ outfits.
content: Every time discussions of fashion intrude on discussions of politics, as they do in moments of high pageantry such as our national party conventions, a certain amount of freaking out ensues. Sexist!, the lament generally goes. Superficial! (That’s the nice version.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: Oh, This Eggplant Lasagna? It Was Nothing.
description: If you roast the eggplant ahead of time, you’re just a half-hour away from a gorgeous, gluten-free vegetarian dinner.
content: My least favorite recipe instructions begin with “Working quickly … ” I have enough pressure in my life. My favorite? “To save time … ”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelle Taft and Libby Leonard
title: On Hawaii’s Big Island, Hurricane Hone Brings Heavy Rain but No Major Damage
description: More than 20,000 customers were without power by Sunday afternoon, but neither the winds nor the flooding from the storm were dramatic.
content: Hurricane Hone passed within 60 miles of Hawaii’s Big Island early Sunday, bringing heavy rain, knocking out power to thousands of customers and snapping native ohia trees like twigs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias
title: How JD Vance Found His Way to the Catholic Church
description: In his 30s, the Republican vice-presidential nominee read works on theology, mysticism, and political and moral philosophy. And he discovered his faith.
content: From his new home in Cincinnati, JD Vance would go to St. Gertrude to meet the friar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: German Prosecutor Says Islamic State Terrorist Link Is Suspected in Festival Stabbings
description: The police say they have arrested a man they believe killed three people and wounded eight others at a festival in the town of Solingen, in western Germany.
content: An attack by a man armed with a knife that left three dead at a local festival in a western German city is being treated as terrorism, with possible links to the Islamic State, German prosecutors said on Sunday
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Aurelien Breeden
title: French Authorities Arrest Suspect in Synagogue Attack
description: Antiterrorism prosecutors said officers had taken a man into custody in connection with a blast outside a synagogue in the southern French resort of La Grande Motte.
content: A suspect who has an arrest record for minor crimes but was not on the radar of French or foreign antiterrorism authorities has been detained in connection with Saturday morning’s attack on a synagogue in southern France, which is being investigated as a terrorist act, French authorities said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Fauci Recovering From West Nile Virus Infection
description: The former director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases had been hospitalized and was expected to make a full recovery, a spokeswoman said.
content: Dr. Anthony Fauci, the former government scientist who was both lauded and criticized for his work on Covid-19, was recently hospitalized with a case of West Nile virus and is recovering at home, according to a spokeswoman for the doctor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Reuters Safety Adviser Killed, 2 Journalists Injured in Strike on Ukraine Hotel
description: Reuters said that a safety adviser working with the journalists was killed, and that two other members of its team were wounded after a hotel in eastern Ukraine was hit in a strike on Saturday.
content: A safety adviser working with a team of journalists for the Reuters news agency was killed on Sunday and two journalists were wounded after a missile hit the hotel in which they were staying in eastern Ukraine, Reuters said in a statement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer
title: Harris Campaign Says It Raised $82 Million During Convention Week
description: The four-day total includes one of the best fund-raising hours of Vice President Kamala Harris’s presidential bid, according to the campaign, which has now raised $540 million in the last month.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris’s presidential campaign said on Sunday that it raised $82 million during the Democratic National Convention last week, the latest spurt of donor enthusiasm around a presidential bid that, according to the campaign, has now raised $540 million in the last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 442
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Aug. 26, 2024
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Brainpower Measures
description: Refrain from making assumptions about Zachary David Levy’s puzzle.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jen Harris
title: Kamala Harris Begins to Sketch a New Economic Vision
description: The vice president is beginning to tell a new story about how the economy works, which could serve as the basis for a governing philosophy that crosses party lines.
content: Kamala Harris is beginning to offer the first definitive clues of a new economic vision — one with the potential not only to offer a unifying vision for the Democratic Party but also to serve as the foundation for a governing philosophy that crosses party lines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martha C. White
title: Why Opening a Roth Account May Be a Good Move, No Matter Your Age
description: These savings accounts, which are often pitched to young investors, can be a good investment option for older and retired workers.
content: At 72, Janice Campbell might not seem like your average investor in a Roth account. Those investment vehicles — funded with after-tax dollars instead of the pretax contributions that go into most individual retirement accounts and 401(k)s — are typically recommended for younger workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Republicans are combing Tim Walz’s record for misstatements.
description: Seeking to blunt the momentum that Vice President Kamala Harris and her running mate, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota, have been experiencing in the polls and hoping to extend after an enthusiastic Democratic National Convention, Republicans have been highlighting small inaccuracies in Mr. Walz’s past descriptions of his résumé.
content: Seeking to blunt the momentum that Vice President Kamala Harris and her running mate, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota, have been experiencing in the polls and hoping to extend after an enthusiastic Democratic National Convention, Republicans have been highlighting small inaccuracies in Mr. Walz’s past descriptions of his résumé.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano, Paul Mozur and Aurelien Breeden
title: Telegram Becomes Free Speech Flashpoint After Founder’s Arrest
description: Pavel Durov, the founder of the app, which has more than 900 million users, was taken into custody by the French authorities.
content: Telegram, founded in 2013 by the Russian entrepreneur Pavel Durov, has grown into one of the world’s largest online communication tools and is central to everyday life in countries like Russia, Ukraine and India for messaging, getting independent news and exchanging views.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: ‘Whatever Happens in the Sauna Stays in the Sauna’: Diplomacy, Conducted in the Nude
description: The Finnish Embassy offers one of the hottest invitations in Washington: a chance to discuss serious topics in a sauna.
content: “When you are half-naked or even sometimes completely naked, it allows for deeper discussion,” said Mikko Hautala, the ambassador of Finland to the United States. “You talk in a way that doesn’t happen when you are sitting around a table with a tie on or at some formal thing.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Greenberg
title: Why Were Justice Dept. Officials Scared to Talk to This Book’s Author?
description: In “Where Tyranny Begins,” the journalist David Rohde reveals how former President Donald Trump tried to use the federal law enforcement agency to help himself and punish his foes.
content: A lot of people seem to have forgotten what made Donald Trump’s presidency so dangerous. Wasn’t it just a lot of loudmouthed name-calling, like tweeting that his own secretary of state was “dumb as a rock”? What did he do that was so terrible after all? NATO is intact, inflammatory policies like the so-called Muslim ban and the southern border wall were mostly thwarted, and the economy did well, at least until Covid. We survived — right?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: Naomi Osaka’s Ruffles and Bows
description: The tennis star unveils her U.S. Open look, made by Nike and the designer Yoon Ahn. It has tulle, ribbons and frills — call it “Lolita goth.”
content: When Naomi Osaka walks onto the court at the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center in Queens, N.Y., this week, she will be covered in bows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Inside the N.F.L.’ and ‘The Bachelorette: Men Tell All’
description: The CW airs their annual show. Jenn Tran confronts her past suitors on ABC.
content: For those who still enjoy a cable subscription, here is a selection of cable and network TV shows, movies and specials that broadcast this week, Aug. 26-Sept. 1. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabby Sobelman, Aaron Boxerman and Hwaida Saad
title: How the Latest Israel-Hezbollah Strikes Unfolded
description: Israel and the Lebanese militia Hezbollah carried out some of their heaviest cross-border attacks in months on Sunday morning.
content: Israel and Hezbollah, the Lebanese militia backed by Iran, have engaged in some of their heaviest cross-border air attacks in months. Israeli aircraft bombarded southern Lebanon on Sunday to stop what Israel said were preparations for a major Hezbollah attack. Hezbollah, the Iranian-backed Lebanese militia, later said it had fired hundreds of rockets and drones at Israel as retribution for Israel’s killing of a senior commander in July, though Israel said there had been little damage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood
title: Dozens Are Killed in Two Unrelated Bus Crashes in Pakistan
description: One of the accidents killed 12 people who were returning from a religious pilgrimage to Iraq, officials said.
content: At least 37 people, including a dozen who were returning from a religious pilgrimage in Iraq, died Sunday in two unrelated bus crashes in Pakistan, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,164
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for August 26, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Monday Briefing: Israel and Hezbollah Exchange Major Attacks
description: Plus, DMZ honey.
content: Israel’s military and Hezbollah fired back and forth in one of the largest cross-border barrages since the war in Gaza began. Here’s the latest.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 25, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Aug. 25, 2025.
content: An article last Sunday about the expansion of abortion clinics misstated the percentage of abortions that are performed in the first trimester of pregnancy. It is 92 percent, not 60 percent. The article also misstated the name of the abortion provider that relocated from North Dakota to Minnesota last year. It is the Red River Women’s Clinic, not the Red River Clinic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien
title: What if China Invades? For Taiwan, a TV Show Raises Tough Questions.
description: Some think the drama, “Zero Day,” helps Taiwan confront an increasingly plausible scenario. Others say the show is alarmist and a tool of the government.
content: On the boulevard in front of the presidential palace in Taipei this weekend, Taiwan’s worst nightmare was unfolding in front of film crews. A crowd of actors and extras portrayed one kind of chaos that might come with a Chinese invasion: a protest descending into violence and bloodshed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: Soaring Insurance Costs Could ‘End’ Affordable Housing, Developers Warn
description: Developers and landlords of subsidized housing, who cannot raise rents or charge more for starter homes, say property insurance increases could put them out of business.
content: For the poorest Americans, finding an apartment to rent or a home to buy often means tapping into a vast network of nonprofit groups that use public and charitable funds to rehab or build affordable housing. Over the past year, the skyrocketing cost of property insurance has put that network on shaky ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David A. Fahrenthold
title: Would a Group Opposed to Police Blow the Whistle on Its Founder?
description: The leader of Raheem AI had a plan to hold law enforcement accountable, but his lavish expenditures derailed the organization.
content: Jasmine Banks’s disillusionment started with a credit-card bill.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Unusual Breed of Dog in Virginia Could Save Life and Limb in Ukraine
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, August 25, 2024.
content: “I could definitely see a future where a drone may find a mine, and then you have somebody who clicks a button that says, ‘Yes, that’s a mine,’ and they click another button to get rid of the mine.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: The Christian Persecution Narrative Rings Hollow
description: We are still trying to figure out how to disentangle church from state (and vice versa).
content: This June, I was invited on a friend’s podcast to answer a question I’ve been asked over and over again in the Trump era. Are Christians really persecuted in the United States of America? Millions of my fellow evangelicals believe we are, or they believe we’re one election away from a crackdown. This sense of dread and despair helps tie conservative Christians, people who center their lives on the church and the institutions of the church, to Donald Trump — the man they believe will fight to keep faith alive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Apple Rethinks Its Movie Strategy After a String of Misses
description: “Wolfs,” a new film starring George Clooney and Brad Pitt, was going to get a robust theatrical release. But the company is curtailing that plan.
content: When Apple won a bidding war in 2021 for the rights to make the action comedy “Wolfs” with George Clooney and Brad Pitt, it did so in part because it promised the stars it would put the movie into a large number of movie theaters.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You May Not Know About the Fish You Eat
description: Readers suggest steps to ensure that seafood is safe, legally caught and properly labeled. Also: The G.O.P.’s Catholic conundrum; blocking emotions.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: These Are Our Favorite Movies From 1999. What Are Yours?
description: In our view, these eight comedies, dramas and more have attained classic status 25 years later. Let us know your own picks.
content: On the 25th anniversary of what many argue is the greatest year in movie history, we asked film staff writers and critics to share the movie from 1999 that they love the best or feel is most overlooked. After reading their picks, let us know your choices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wolfgang Ischinger
title: To Whom It May Concern: America and Europe Need Each Other
description: The trans-Atlantic alliance can continue as the tight-knit partnership we have known for the past 75 years, or unravel.
content: The funny thing about being a European during American presidential elections is the belief that you, too, should be allowed to vote. And can you blame us? Who gets to occupy the Oval Office is correctly seen by many in Europe as a decision of existential significance for the well-being and security of the continent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: On Immigration, Harris and Democrats Walk a Delicate — and Harder — Line
description: The message Democrats put forward at their convention last week, a tougher line than in decades, reflects how deeply immigration remains a political vulnerability for the party.
content: When Vice President Kamala Harris accepted the Democratic presidential nomination last week at her party’s convention in Chicago, she sought to strike a delicate balance on the issue of immigration, promising to approach enforcement and security at the nation’s southern border as the prosecutor she once was, without abandoning the country’s values.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman, Isabel Kershner and Euan Ward
title: In a Region on Edge, Israel and Hezbollah Launch Major Attacks on Each Other
description: The escalating strikes across the Israel-Lebanon border fueled fears of a bigger conflagration, but both sides signaled that they were de-escalating, for now.
content: Amid fears of an all-out war between Israel and Hezbollah forces in Lebanon, the two sides on Sunday mounted the biggest round of cross-border strikes since the war in Gaza began, with Israel bombing dozens of sites in a pre-emptive attack, and Hezbollah launching hundreds of rockets and drones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Mitzi McCall, Comedian Who Confronted Beatlemania and Lost, Dies at 93
description: She and her husband had the bad luck to make their “Ed Sullivan Show” debut the same night as the Beatles. They bombed. But their careers would recover.
content: In the decades after they made their first appearance on “The Ed Sullivan Show,” on Feb. 9, 1964, the comedy team of Mitzi McCall and her husband, Charlie Brill, had a successful career. They performed in nightclubs and on television; both individually and together, they acted on television, in films and onstage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Knight and Alexandra Berzon
title: As Kamala Harris Claims Oakland, Berkeley Forgives
description: The vice president has virtually erased Berkeley, Calif., her hometown, from her campaign biography. The residents of “the People’s Republic” say they get it.
content: High above an arena packed with Democratic delegates in Chicago last week, a video introduced the life story of Kamala Harris to the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: Trying to Head Off War, U.S. Moves Naval Forces Closer to Israel
description: American officials are sending a signal to Iran and its allies, in the form of two aircraft carrier groups and a guided-missile submarine.
content: With fears rising that a wider war could break out in the Middle East, the United States has steadily been moving Navy forces closer to the area, including two aircraft carrier groups and a guided-missile submarine. And it has not been shy about announcing the details, in a clear effort to deter Iran and its allies from more intense attacks on Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aida Alami
title: The Young Frenchman Striving to Give Voice to a Troubled Area
description: As a teenager, Amine Kessaci confronted Emmanuel Macron, founded an environmental group and lost a brother to drug violence. At 20, he almost won a National Assembly seat.
content: At 17, Amine Kessaci found himself seated close to the president of France, Emmanuel Macron, who had come to Marseille to kick off his second presidential campaign in 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Ellsworth
title: What the Lobstermen of Maine Tell Us About the Election
description: There are places in America where climate change feels close at hand — and also far away from politics, partly because of how much work there is to do.
content: Mid-July is peak season on the central Maine coast. The blueberries — the small, low-bush kind long prized by the state’s jam makers and pie bakers — had started to appear in the farmers markets, along with the first of the tomatoes. Bright orange tiger lilies burst from front yards, while Queen Anne’s lace and goldenrod line the two-lane roads. The summer light dazzles, falling in soft waves upon the spruce and cedar, and brightening the paint on both midcentury saltboxes and grander Victorian homes. It’s no wonder that people want to come here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Yuhas
title: Questions for Investigators Trying to Unravel Mystery of Luxury Yacht’s Sinking
description: The investigators searching for answers about the shipwreck, leaving seven dead, face questions about extreme weather and possible human error or problems with the yacht itself.
content: More than 180 feet long, with a mast towering about 240 feet and a keel that could be lowered for greater stability, the Bayesian luxury yacht did not, in the eyes of its maker, have the vulnerabilities of a ship that would easily sink.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius, Maria Cramer and Wesley Parnell
title: How a Migrant Accused of Rape Was Freed and Charged With Rape Again
description: A failure of cooperation between New York City and federal authorities allowed Daniel Davon-Bonilla, a 24-year-old from Nicaragua, to slip out of the grasp of law enforcement.
content: For 15 months, Daniel Davon-Bonilla sat in the Rikers Island jail complex in New York City, accused of raping a transgender woman in a migrant shelter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjana Sankar
title: Here’s a Timeline of Recent Strikes and Retaliations in the Middle East
description: Tensions in the region had been high for weeks before Israel and Hezbollah began more intense cross-border attacks early Sunday.
content: Before Sunday’s attacks, tensions in the Middle East had been high for weeks in the wake of high-profile assassinations of senior leaders of the militant groups Hamas and Hezbollah.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Noticed That the Woman in the Orange Shirt Was Losing Her Balance’
description: Trying not to fall on a moving train, a message between old friends and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Saporito
title: There Are a Bazillion Possible Starbucks Orders — and It’s Killing the Company
description: Starbucks is struggling with an overly complex menu.
content: You’re already in line at Starbucks — having failed to order by app — when you spot one of them. That dude who is looking down not at a cellphone but at the Post-it note that holds the orders of his office mates. Which is confirming that you are going to be late for that next meeting, because this person plans to order six coffee beverages, each of which involves some combination of tall venti grande double-pump, one to four shots of espresso, half-caf, oat milk, nonfat milk, soy milk, milk milk, whipped cream, syrup, brown sugar, white sugar, no sugar and mocha drizzle, from the pike position with two and a half twists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Bloch, William B. Davis, Madison Dong, Judson Jones, John Keefe and Bea Malsky
title: Tracking Tropical Storm Hector
description: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Hector.
content: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Hector.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Axel Boada and McKinnon de Kuyper
title: Israel and Hezbollah Trade Heavy Air Attacks
description: Israel on Sunday launched what it described as a pre-emptive strike against a major attack that Hezbollah was planning on Israeli territory. Hezbollah fired its own barrage later in the day.
content: Israel on Sunday launched what it described as a pre-emptive strike against a major attack that Hezbollah was planning on Israeli territory. Hezbollah fired its own barrage later in the day.
source.name: The New York Times
